Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Elizabeth Gross is "Geometry and Algebra of Statistical Models." The host institution for the fellowship is North Carolina State University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Seth Sullivant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to study statistical graphical models in the setting of algebraic statistics. The goals were two-fold: first, investigate problems in combinatorial commutative algebra and computational algebraic geometry that arise from the theory of graphical models, and second, develop statistical methodology for graphical models using algebraic geometry. 

For this project, the PI and co-authors studied Gaussian graphical models, statistical models used in biological applications; statistical network models, models used to capture edge formation mechanisms in social and biological networks; and biochemical reaction networks, deterministic models used in systems biology.

In terms of Gaussian graphical models, the PI and co-authors used algebraic matroids to connect a statistical invariant of the models, the maximum likelihood threshold, to rigidity theory, a field motivated by problems in engineering.  

In terms of network models, the PI and co-authors developed a new goodness-of-fit algorithm for log-linear network models.  This will allow researchers from sociology to neuroscience to test whether a particular model of edge formation fits their data.  This new algorithm was based on concepts in combinatorial comuutative algebra.

Finally, in terms of biochemical reaction networks, the PI and co-authors describe a procedure for parameter estimation and model selection for such networks.  The method applies numerical algebraic geometry to the model selection problem with effective results.

As far as broader impacts are concerned, one part of this project was to develop software for statisticians and researchers in other fields based on the ideas and theories from algebraic statistics.  To this end, the PI was a co-author of the software package that makes it easier to use numerical algebraic geometry techniques within existing computer algebra programs.

Additionally, this award allowed for new collaborations to be built. The PI worked with a total of 20 collaborators on the 9 research products related to this award.  The PI's collaborators were from a total of 17 different institutions, 4 of which were outside the U.S., and 3 which were primarily undergraduate institutions. Of these 20 collaborators, 8 were graduate students, and 3 were postdocs.

Modified by: Elizabeth A Gross
